ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Instructor was not very helpful in facilitating class discussions.

Q 12. This class is very broad. That means that at times the content can be a bit vague or disconnected, but it allows students endless amount of latitude to pursue your own interests. This class is great for anyone with a food or food-related interest.
Erin and Gordon worked very well together. The course was organized, and I liked the unconventional structure.Overall really great class
n.a
A great place to expose yourself to critical thinking, innovation, and food systems study.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Some of the speakers were great! Peter Tyedmers, Jennifer Blesh, Bill Mebane, and Fred Kaufman were the standouts.

Erin Schnettler, the TF did a phenomenal job organizing the speakers for this class and the opportunity to go out to dinner with the speakers after they spoke was far and away the best part of the class. This gave me the chance to follow up and go in depth on a variety of topics and it gave the speakers a chance to get to know the students more. All were excited about talking with Forestry students and excited to hear feedback about their talks and innovations, and I hope that this can continue onto next year as well.Allowing each of the students to explore their own innovation and then present to the class was also a great way to share ideas and allow the diverse interests in the class to be explored.Learning about risk analysis and learning how to use metrics and methods of quantifying risk was valuable aspects of the course.
This class allows a lot of flexibility and independent inquiry. It enables students whose interest in food may not be well-represented elsewhere to pursue questions that interest them.
It's one of the few ones on food!The LCAs of various food systems were valuable.I didn't know anything about the importance of aquaculture before - learning that was useful.
I liked our discussions toward the end of the year.
Guest speakers, diversity of thoughts from presenters and classmates
Discussion sections were engaging and brought out a lot of great critical thought, especially as the semester progressed.
The guest lectures were well planned.
Guest speaker based seminar series are my favorite

The memos we wrote were really interesting, because we learned a lot writing them and got to hear a lotof interesting ideas from our classmates when they presented! Class discussions were also interesting, especially later in the semester when the structure became a bit firmer. The guest speakers were also great!!!!
I loved hearing from all of the guest speakers. Having guest speakers allowed us to cover a wide range of topics--all of which I found fascinating.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Need a course facilitator/instructor more familiar with the subject, if possible, which would also give the course some continuity from year-to-year, hopefully.

I think it's important to have more structure to the Wednesday classes when we didn't have a speaker. Classtime discussions could be more directed at critiquing the discussed innovation and coming up with alternatives or solutions to risks and barriers. There were several classes when we broke up into groups and had smaller, project-based discussions before coming back together as a class and I thought this was an incredibly effective way of engaging with the course materialI also think that the speaker experiences could have been improved if each student were to come up with a list of questions to submit the day before the speaker came and then the TF could circulate these questions to the speaker to prepare them. Instead of using almost the full time for a speaker and only the last couple minutes for questions, using half of the time for questions would lead to a richer and more engaging experience for all.I would also recommend giving students better and stricter guidelines for final papers. There was a wide variety both in the subjects of the final paper as well as the quality of the final presentations, and it would be good for everyone to have clearer standards to comply with.

The structure was a bit disconnected at times - a natural hazard to a guest speaker-based course. It would also be interesting areas other than technology and a format beyond the standard 15-page report.
It's hard to have a good discussion based class when many students (including me sometimes) are so naive.More basics taught early on would be useful.
More readings (guided with more critical thinking about topics, not just background reading).
I would have liked additional discussion time following lectures.
Some of the speakers were not so great.
There needs to be more focus in the discussions on Mondays.

Although very relevant to modern innovation and global food systems, I think the choice of speakers and content in general overlooked the idea of food system improvements and the idea of how they can be adapted or improved for the future, instead focusing on how things currently are without any suggestion that they need drastic overhaul if we are to address the food problems of today.
Organization of class structure

This is most likely a logistical issue that comes from accommodating so many different guest speaker schedules, but some of the modules were a little bit scattered. There wasn't a flow from one guest speaker to the next. Again, that could be largely unavoidable.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Discussion could have been more grounded in the speakers and next year it would be great to focus directly on what the speakers said or coming up with questions for the upcoming speaker.

I really liked the link between the guest lectures and class discussion. Class discussion provided a good balance between factual content and open discussion of the speaker& theme. The speakers could be a little hit-or-miss at times, so this forum was a great 'debrief.'
I though the unconventional structure where speakers assign reading, give a talk, and we discuss both the talk and the reading separately was affective.
n/a
Great discussion sections. Deeply relevant to the material. The better we discussed something before a speaker came, the better questions and often better lecture we received.
The relationship was effective, but too much time was focused on the lecture from the week before.
there weren't really discussion sections, but I liked talking about the speakers afterwards in class!
The discussion section was incredibly effective. I learned as much from my peers as I did from the guest speakers.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This class is a must for food people. It creates a great forum for people with similar (but extremely diverse!) interests and encourages students to bring their own interests and expertise to the table.
One creditors did not receive any feedback on critical reviews, the only requirement for the course for these students. Occasional feedback would have been helpful.
I learned a lot about what innovations are out there and what is happening on the frontiers of food so that was helpful.
I'm interested in food systems and entrepreneurship so this class was right up my alley.

This class allowed me to explore my academic interests and see which specific strands of my field appeal to me. Because the speakers came from such a diversity of backgrounds and occupations, it also opened my mind to the paths I could take after school, which was invaluable!!

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I'm a food person. It's a food class. There aren't many alternatives. Plus I was excited about getting exposure to guest speakers from both the applied& academic worlds. I wanted to hone my own area of interest but also learn moreabout commodities& issues I was less familiar with.
Because it directly relates to my academic interests.
n/a
I am interested in the ecological, economic and social impacts associated with large-scale agriculture, particularly commodity crops and beef production.
See above
I wanted to take a class at the forestry school before graduating.
It fit really well with my interests!
I am interested in sustainable food systems, and how the food system is changing.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes. I learned more about academic research on food production and more about global commodities in general.

I would have liked slightly more content at times. I sometimes feel like I just go through school reinforcing my previously help opinions, biases and knowledge. I'm grateful for the opportunity to share my knowledge and experience, but I sure wish I could learn from other people a bit more. This is more of an FES issue that a critique of this class, I suppose.
Lots of learning and the final project was helpful in thinking through some bigger issues.
Yes.
This was a perfect course for me.
Yes.
Students would have been better served to learn about trend-setting and system-testing food innovations rather than being informed about market direction and current food-system weak points.
risk assessment, a broader understanding of the food system
Absolutely! I learned so much from this course. The readings, discussion, instructors and speakers were all wonderful

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: There were opportunities to work in groups for the final project, and I thought that this was a really valuable part of the course, especially because innovations are increasingly becoming products of collaborations between individuals in different fields. Group work in the context of social and technological innovations is extremely important and fulfilling!

I really enjoyed co-facilitating with my group. I was grateful that I didn't have to spend more than a week working on a group project (by choice - many people did), but I also liked having a small group project.
n/a

My partner and I were able to support one another and critically explore our research topic in a way that wouldn't be as easy to do alone. Our project really grew out of critical discussions we had together, and we were able to use each other as sounding boards for our ideas and critiques.
I think it's always important to practice working as a group because it mimics real world situations. Sometimes it was frustrating, but I think we produced better work than we would have alone!

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Read the class literature on the guest speaker and lookup the background of the guest speaker before they come to class because it will lead to a more enriching and engaging lecture. I'd also recommend coming up with a list of questions to ask because the lectures were always more interesting when students jumped in right away and asked questions to turn the lecture into a discussion rather than a simple powerpoint presentation.Also, always, always take the opportunity to go to dinner with the guest speaker after class!And do a final paper on something you're truly interested in!!!!

Take this class! It is a rare and wonderful opportunity at FES to get exactly what you want out of a course. Both the instructor& the TA were extremely helpful& flexible& genuinely want to help you extract value from the experience.
Take it if you like lecturers.
Go for it! It is relevant to every field of study at FES whether that's business, ecology, economics, climate, food, water, development, really everything is relevant to this course.
Take it for three credits, the additional work is not that great.
take lots of notes, ask lots of questions, challenge the speakers
I think you get out of this course what you put into it. Do the readings! Ask questions of the speakers! Pick a really cool final project! Hang out with Erin and Gordon!

I would recommend this class to anyone interested insustainable food/agriculture. I would definitely advise that they go into the class thinking about innovations/tackling problems, as opposed to looking at the class as an in depth analysis of issues within the food system.
